headline: Best Ever Pie Crust
description: This pie crust recipe with shortening uses only four ingredients and is simple to make. The result is a very flaky crust that's perfect for any pie.
name: Best Ever Pie Crust
recipeIngredient: 1 cup shortening, cut into small pieces and frozen for 30 minutes
0.5 cup ice-cold water, or as needed

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk together flour and salt in a large bowl. Cut in chilled shortening with a pastry blender until the mixture resembles coarse, pea-sized crumbs.

Add 1/4 cup ice-cold water; use a fork to stir the flour up from the bottom, just until it's mixed in. Press down on any chunks and continue working the dough around the bowl. Continue to add ice-cold water, in 1 tablespoon increments, mixing just until dough is moist enough to hold together when molded; you will not need more than 4 tablespoons and in fact, may need less. Do not add too much water!

Gently gather dough together into a ball. Divide in half, and flatten each half into a 1-inch-thick disc. Wrap each disc in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes. For best results, chill for 4 hours, or up to 2 days.
When ready to use, roll dough on a lightly floured surface, being careful not to overwork it.
Fit dough into a pie plate. If it crumbles or tears as you work it, just pinch and press it back into shape.
Use as directed in your pie recipe.

review.reviewBody: I was very pleased with this crust - it was easy to work with and came out nice and flakey. I used 1/2 regular Crisco and 1/2 Butter flavored Crisco. Was kind of curious about a whole cup of shortening, but it ended up being good.
Way too much shortening. I use about 5 tablespoons of shortening with one cup of flour for a single crust pie. It turns out fine every time.
I used this to make my first ever pies. My pies turned out great and I got a lot of compliments on the crust! I'm thrilled. The crust was flakey and light, with great flavor.
Easy recipe and the pastry was flaky and perfect.
We've been looking for a great vegan crust for quite some time, and this is it! The pie crust turned out so light and flaky! I think freezing the shortening ahead of time makes such a difference.

This was a very easy pie dough to work with. I only chilled the dough for an hour, but it came out perfect. I used lard instead of shortening. When you are getting "almost there" with the water, wet your hand and knead the dough rather than adding it by the spoonful.
Super easy, Loved it!

This is the recipe I have used for years - given to me by a lady that owned a restaurant and baked apple pies every week. People loved her pies and everyone always loved mine. I guess the secret is, don't work the dough too much. Toss it gently until it forms a ball, refrigerate, then roll!
I have made this pie crust my whole life and I am 72 years old, Mom made it before me, always flaky
This dough was very sticky and broke easily (even though I refrigerated overnight), however, the baked crust was super flaky and tasty.
This worked perfectly. Pumpkin pies were fantastic with the made from scratch crust. Easy to make.

I made this recipe for a chicken and leek pie. I followed the recipe exactly. It looked beautiful but the taste and texture was awful. It left a filmy, fatty and almost grainy feeling in your mouth. It ruined the delicious filling that I had made. I wish I would have read the reviews closer. I think that the proportions of flour and veg shortening are off. There are a lot of pie crust recipes out there. I recommend using a different one!
Excellent crust. Needs to be kept super cold to work with it though.

This piecrust is excellent however what is not mentioned in the main recipe is that your butter or shortening must be chilled and you must use ice water. Cutting in the butter or shortening to pea size and then adding the ice water slowly makes this recipe excellent. You may need to chill the dough before rolling out but all in all this has been a winner. I truly believe that the negative comments are from making this without chilled ingredients. I have used this recipe many times and it has always been excellent with the rave reviews from those consuming it.
I’ve never made pie crust in my life. I made it in my food processor in 5 mins and it turned out fantastic. Not the healthiest but very yummy! Highly recommend for beginners
Crust was so flaky and the bottom was beautifully browned. I used part butter since I was short on the correct amount of Crisco. Will make again for sure.
Way way too much shortening...Makes this crust way to difficult to work with...I won't be making it again....crust just crumbles.

I usually read the good and bad reviews and this time I didn’t and I’m sorry I didn’t. I was so taken by the reviews about flakiness I just jumped in. I followed the recipe and chilled every thing. The crust was a bit difficult to work with but I muddled through. After baking it was beautiful . It was the taste that Makes me give this recipe 1 star. In a word - greeeaasy. WOW! After a couple of bites of this pie my lips feel as though I put on several layers of lip balm. I hate to do this after all the work, but this pie along with the recipe is going in the dumper.

My first time making meat pies and I needed a basic pie dough recipe. Quick and easy to mix. I did not plan ahead, so there was no time to chill the dough. End result was a light, flaky delicate crust-just what I wanted. Baked at 350 degrees for 40 mins.

I've been making this recipe for years and it's a no fail recipe that my family loves and if you didn't make it right like one complainer it's because you either mixed it too long or too much ingredients but you can mix unsalted butter instead or half and half shortening
Great recipe

I made this recipe exactly as written and it made a fantastic pie crust. I used it for apple and am using it for mixed berry. I really don't understand the negative review at all. I just figure those people aren't good at baking.
Really enjoyed this recipe.

I did not change a thing in this recipe.I was a little worried after reading the top negative review because after I made the dough it did seem somewhat crumbly but i let it chill overnight in the fridge and that did the trick, made sure not to overwork it when rolling it out. Beautiful pie crust. 100% recommend.
My go-to pie crust recipe. Everyone loves it
Simple and easy!

Best pie crust I have ever made. The only change, and it's because I like the buttery flavor, was to use 1/2 cup butter and 1/2 cup shortening. Followed recipe besides that. 
The crust was so flakey. My daughter said it with the residue of my pecan pie tasted like baklava.
Def have this one saved for future use!

I used old fashioned lard and it really came out just like what your grandmother used to make. The key to the recipe is to make sure your lard/shortening/butter is hard (not too hard) so that it can be broken into the pieces described. Follow the measurements as they are spot on and you will have the best crust at your next gathering.

I followed the recipe exactly as stated. The dough was easy to work with when I took it out of the refrigerator. Made a wonderful tasting and flaky crust. I do use Crisco butter flavored shortening, which makes it taste more buttery.

I didnt realize I needed to chill the recipe for 4 hours so I stuck it in the freezer for about 15-20 mins and it was perfect! I followed the recipe exactly and had no issues. The dough rolled perfectly and did not crack or fall apart.
Made it as is, turned out great. My family loved it...

This is the exact recipe my Mom used many years ago.
She wou;d make several at a time and freeze them, wrap them well in plastic wrap before a holiday or busy time. When she wanted some she would let them defrost on the counter and as soon as they were ready, finish the pie and bake them. Every woman who tasted her pies asked for the dough recipe.( She never left them too long in the freezer. ) 
We loved her pies !!

Awesome recipe!!

Loved it the first time 4 years ago. After that, tried to change the fats and see what would happen....1/2 shortening and 1/2 butter seems to me the best for our tastes. Otherwise, everything is spot on - keep making it over and over. A pie crust should be loaded with fat, that's what gives you the buttery lovely flaky quality. Another key - don't over mix or over process! Just to incorporate. The heat from your the friction of hands/rollers as you work to roll out your crust will keep mixing - it should be a 'shaggy dough' or a rough dough having incorporated at least 3/4 of the flour, that you turn out onto a surface to work with. The additional flour will work in as you gently work roll/ shape the crust. Don't overwork your dough/crust! Just work until you can shape it, roll it and move on with the glorious pie making of all types!
I add 2 TB sugar and 1 TB almond extract if baking into a sweet pie.

I don’t have much experience making pie crust. When I have made it in the past, it wasn’t great. This recipe was easy to follow and the crust was excellent. I made a lemon meringue pie, and everyone loved it. I’ll definitely use it again.
I love this recipe! I make it for homemade apple pie, it was simple and delicious!

Made the recommended changes to half butter half shortening, reduced salt slightly, added much less water due to high humidity. Remember to keep chill, and if during the process things get soggy, chuck it back into the fridge for a while. 
I think I've found the crust recipe I'm looking for!

Best, flaky crust I’ve ever had, Nd my husband loved and complimented it. Wow! However!!! It was hard to work with. Kept falling apart. Seemed like it was going to be a tough crust. I was unhappy when I put it in the oven. Threw out the recipe. When we tasted it, boy were we surprised. Had to go search for the recipe. It’s a keeper, even if it gives me trouble!!
Perfection! I used butter flavored shortening! Flakey and delicious!

Foolproof! I am not a good baker, but this pie crust makes it seem as if I am. The sis the flakiest crust and does not crack at all. It works so well, that you won't risk overworking it cause it rolls out like dream. Definitely chill the shortening, it really adds to the flakiness. I use it for pies, and for chicken pot pie and steak pie as well.

wow the best recipe ever for pie crust, quick, easy and delicious. I have been making pies since I was in High school. Always hated making crust, still do. Tried this one today with a chicken pot pie, even the bottom crust was perfect without pre baking THANK YOU.
First recipe from here that I can use without changes
Excellent! This pie crust is nice and flaky. I have made it several times and it always turnns out great.
Excellent! Turned out nice and flaky. I substituted butter for shortening and it tured out delicious.
I have made this many times and it is fantastic. Follow it to the letter and you will be pleased. I use it for fruit pies and quiches as well with no substitutions.
Will definitely make this again!
Instructions were great. Just hope mine turns out like it is supposed to (Is currently resting in icebox).
Instructions were great. Just hope mine turns out like it is supposed to (Is currently resting in icebox).

This recipe is the best! I had not attempted a from scratch pie crust in many years, and was nerv ous that I wouldn't be able to make a good crust. My mother was a great pie baker and a tough act to follow. But by following this recipe (including the "chill time" for the shortening and dough), I was able to produce a crust every bit as good as Mom's (don't tell her). This will be my go to recipe going forward.

I made the recipe as written chilling the shortening and water as shown in the video. Used a pastry cutter and didn't overwork it. It worked very well and was flaky. I will use this simple quick recipe again for fruit pies. I used it for a meat pie this time but think that it will suit a sweet pie better.

I made as directed, using my food processor instead of a pastry blender. I needed less water than called for, only used about 6 tablespoons.
This came together really well!

Made this pie crust for the first time. Followed the instructions exactly and made a Rustic Peach Pie. The pie filling was great, but the crust wasn’t. I used grated frozen butter, added it to the flour and salt, then mixed it with enough ice water to make a ball, flattened it and then wrapped in plastic and put back into the fridge. We had to cut the crust with a knife to eat it. It was very chewy. When I took the pie out of the oven, it looked as if it was sitting in a pool of grease! Probably too much butter in the crust. Won’t try this recipe again. Maybe I should go back to the Crisco pie crust recipe that’s on the box, but I’ve read some interesting things about Crisco and maybe I won’t go back to it. I’ve never tried Tenderflake though! ????
it came out great
This was the first pie crust I attempted. I found it not only easy, but delicious! I have made this several times now and it has been perfect every time.
Flakiest crust ever. It's all about the method.
I live in the tropics and pie crusts are near impossible. I increased the flour by 1/2 cup. The best pie crust I have ever made.

Please read all the reviews before trying this recipe. I read them all and still tried it. I will NEVER use it again. All the negative reviews I read were correct regarding (greasy texture, difficult to work with, too sticky, doesn't roll out). I chilled it, that didn't help, I put it between plastic wrap while rolling and then didn't help. I even pieced some of it together and baked it to see how it would taste. I'll have to admit after all this, it tasted flaky but it was impossible to work and roll so it looked decent. Trust me--get another recipe and save yourself some frustration. I will not use it again or recommend it. I used the ingredients as listed.

This dough was just too wet. It falls apart and sticks to the rolling pin while rolling and shrinks a lot once it's baked. It's also not very pretty and just looks greasy. It's edible, but that's about it.
I loved the recipe and it was easy to make
easy,needed less water
The absolute best pie crust
If you want to cook the crust separatly, cook it for about 20 minutes!
This recipe is delicious I definitely recommend it

This crust was very good! I followed the recipe exactly as directed, but I chilled the water and shortening for about an hour before I made my dough. I doubled the recipe, and it made about 1.5 times what I needed. I rolled my crust out a bit too thick at about 1/8" (I made a cherry pie), so next time I think a much thinner crust would be much tastier for a fruit pie. My crust turned out flaky, just the right amount of moist, and was quite simple to make. I also followed the tip of another reviewer and rolled my dough out between two pieces of plastic wrap, which worked wonderfully.

I used only 1/4 cup of water which was almost too much already.
It's tastes very good and is flaky!
Light flaky deliciousness!! I substituted half the butter for half lard. i will definitely be using this recipe again. I used it for all our pies for the holidays :)

Totally agree with the other negative reviews. Way too much shortening to flour ratio. Without even adding any water it resembled a soft cookie dough. Ended up adding close to an additional 3/4 cup of flour to even make it resemble a pie dough. Won't be making it again.
I made this for my pumpkin pie and it came out great. I had no issues at all working with this dough. I followed directions just as posted and all went well. Highly recommend it.

Let me start by saying I can't stand making pie crust, but we have a ton of apples and I don't like the taste of the store-made crusts. I hit up All Recipes to see what I could find and I decided to try this recipe. This recipe is *so easy* to make and it came out perfectly. I chilled the dough for only 45 min or so, 10 min in the freezer. This is my go-to recipe for pie crust from now on! Thanks!!

4 stars only because if you are new to pie crust making you must read the reviews for the tips that make this pie crust successful. You MUST refrigerate or freeze the shortening, the pastry cutter, and add ice cubes to the water and strain to the correct amount. If you do those things this is a 5 star recipe. I wanted a bit of a buttery flavor so I substituted 1/2 C cold butter for 1/2 the shortening. I am a baker but I specialize in cakes. This was my first attempt at pie crust and it came out great. I used it for apple dumplings. It was easy to work with, held together beautifully was tender and flaky. Follow the the tips and you too will be a pie or dumpling maker..thanks for the recipe and thank you to all reviewers who covered the tips..Will be using again!!

Make sure to pop it in the fridge while you make the filling to keep the fats cold. If you leave it on the counter it will become greasy (obviously). I rolled it onto a floured surface and it was great. Beware that this makes enough for a crust and top. Or one really thick crust. Will make again.
I didn't use any water on account of the fact the dough was already extremely soft and difficult to work with. I think this recipe has too much shortening.
I didn't care for this recipe. Very greasy.

I did like recipe called for.
Very tender crust, was very pleased
Half fat to flour is the perfect ratio that I have been using for over 50 years. My only difference is I use lard not shortening because I prefer the taste in the pastry.
Made recipe as written. Came out too crisco-e. Added 1/2 cup more of flour and omitted water. Great basic pie crust recipe. 5 stars when you add 1/2 cup flour/Zero water :)

This was the first pie crust I have ever attempted. I chose it for its ease and was greatly impressed with the results. I followed the other reviews that said use 1/2 cup of butter and 1/2 cup shortening. Super flaky and buttery crust. It was absolutely wonderful. If you are a beginner I would highly suggest chilling it as suggested as it made the dough super easy work. For anyone who is wondering, this recipe will make enough dough. For a top and bottom crust. I was curious about that as no one else had said it yet. I will definitely be using this as make pie crust on all my pies in the future. Cheers!
Instead of using all shortening, I used 1/2 shortening and the other 1/2 butter. Worked really well.

I have always had trouble with homemade pie crusts, but have never found a frozen crust that matched the flaky crust of my grandmothers pies. No matter what I do, its always either too dry or too sticky. This recipe was easy and a typical shortening-based crust. Overall, simple to make, but also simple to make wrong. I used another reviewers suggestion and rolled out the dough between two pieces of saran wrap, which helped rolling it out even though it was really sticky. On the second try I found it worked even better by sprinkling the saran wrap with flour on both sides first. The taste was good and the crust was very flaky. So even though I still find it a pain, it was everything a flaky crust should be.
This is an awesome recipe
Perfection! SO EASY. Used tenderflake lard, because I was out of shortening.

I've been using this recipe for over 30 years and have never had a problem - I can't imagine a low rating especially if you didn't even bother to finish and taste it or you didn't follow the instructions. It has a lot of shortening in it so the refrigeration is important. If you don't know how to make a pie crust try watching one of the videos on here, it's important to know the tricks such as adding water 1 tablespoon at a time until you hit the right consistency and know what the right consistency is. This is an excellent almost foolproof recipe for great pie crust.
I use this recipe all t time, however i use lard rather than shortening. Always turns out great :)

Very good pie crust and super easy. Very flakey! I didn't refrigerate it for the full 4 hours, only about an hour in the fridge, and it still rolled out good and tasted great. I used this crust on my Turkey Pot Pie, and was a perfect size for a double crust recipe. Still had a little left over. :)

Turns out perfect every time , very simple recipe to follow , I find it easiest to just make the crust a batch at a time then I don't need to split it when I roll it out , very flakey , everyone ask for the recipe , I bake pies for the vets home in Minneapolis and every one is asking for the crust recipe !
Best ever , easy crust. Did substitute shortening with lard for the most flaky crust ever !!
So good. Flaky and delicious. Is a little challenging to roll out but chilling it well is helpful.

This has become the only pie crust I use. It's flaky and everyone who eats it tells me it's the best they've ever tasted. Keep everything cold, that's the key. And, pay attention to the water amount. I find I use less than called for usually. I've sped up the process by putting the dough in the freezer when I've been pressed for time. I don't understand the negative reviews as this recipe has not failed me and I've made over 30 pies with it.

This is my go to pie crust recipe. You have to follow the directions precisely, and it creates a sturdy flaky crust that does not get soggy in the middle like some of the other recipes I've tried before. This pie crust stands up to almost any thing I put in it from Apple pie to chicken pot pie. I don't change anything, just follow as directed!

Absolutely the best pie crust. I don't make any changes except I roll it and put it in a pie tin before chilling it. I find cold dough is too hard to work with, and people still rave about the crust regardless.
This crust was very hard to work with. I ended up rolling it on cling wrap to get it to transfer to my pie pan. It was tasteless and extremely crumbly, although visually very flaky.
I cut this in half for 1 pie. The less you mix it, the flakier the crust. Mix it with a fork just until it's all moist.
Followed this recipe exactly, it was awesome. Very crispy and flaky'

I followed this recipe to a T - it's very good - good for a savoury (bacon and egg) pie, as well as a sweet one (Treacle Tart). I doubled the recipe and froze the shells. Used two this morning and they're great. My husband even commented on how good the pastry was. I'll be using this recipe again. Thanks Jean Haseloh.
Easy and yummy perfect and simple!!!!

Definitely a bit hard to work with, hence the 4 stars, but I found it worth it in the end. I'm not known for good crusts, so when this came out really good.... Well you can imagine my pleasure... Note: If you use salted butter or whatever, don't add the salt, or cut way back.... way... lol. My bad.
My family & I love this crust!! I made a couple revisions. I only used 1/2 cup of butter & added 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spice & sugar to make it sweeter! Fabulous!!

This was great! I did half/half butter and shortening, froze them both and then grated it, so much easier to combine, easy to handle and turned out very nice and flaky! Will be my new go-to piecrust for both sweet and savioury pies. Left out the salt, since I used salted butter.
This is by far the best pie crust recipe I have used.
There was way too much shortening and it was impossible to work with. It just fell apart and there was no way to get it into a pie tin.
